I am a PhD student in the hybrid systems and controls lab at the University of New Mexico, and a graduate student researcher at Sandia National Laboratories in the Autonomy for Hypersonics group. My principal research interests include stochastic reachability, theory and applications of kernel methods, statistical learning algorithms, and autonomous systems.
My research is focused on developing algorithms to solve approximate stochastic reachability problems to provide probabilistic guarantees of safety for autonomous and human-in-the-loop systems. I am also interested in applying kernel distribution embeddings to perform estimation and controller synthesis for complex controls problems.

content:
Safety is defined as a set of constraints that prohibit a system from entering certain states. This could be preventing a quadrotor from hitting a tree, preventing an autonomous car from driving on the sidewalk, etc. Stochastic reachability is a technique to determine the probability that a system will remain safe over some time horizon. Using these techniques, we can also ensure that a system will reach a target set with a certain likelihood, and we can compute control actions that will maximize the probability of reaching the target. Even though we use the term “safety”, this is a general term that doesn't always mean we are only interested in avoiding literal crashes or explosions.
Formally, the system is defined as a Markov control process, which is a 3-tuple, $\mathcal{H} = (\mathcal{X}, \mathcal{U}, Q)$, consisting of:
 $\mathcal{X}$ is the state space, which is the set of all possible states the system can occupy. $\mathcal{U}$ is the control space, which is the set of all possible control inputs. $Q : \mathscr{B}(\mathcal{X}) \times \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{U} \rightarrow [0, 1]$ is a stochastic kernel.  The state space is usually defined by the physics of the system. If we are dealing with a spacecraft, for example, we typically define $\mathcal{X} \subseteq \Re^{n}$. This means there are $n$ state variables that can take real values. The control space is also usually defined in a similar fashion. Some problems allow the controller to take on a wide array of values, others restrict the control inputs to a small admissible set of possible inputs. In the general case, $\mathcal{U} \subseteq \Re^{m}$, and there are $m$ different inputs that we can control.
The stochastic kernel $Q$ is the most important part of the system definition, because it actually describes how the system changes over time. For every state $x \in \mathcal{X}$ and control input $u \in \mathcal{U}$, there exists a probability measure $Q(x'|x,u)$ that describes the likelihood that a system will reach any future state $x’ \in \mathcal{X}$. For some future states, the probability may equal zero because it is physically impossible to move there. Things can't just teleport through solid objects, for example. This means the probability of moving to some states will be low or zero, while the probability of moving to other more probable states will be higher. In general, when we are dealing with a stochastic system, the probability of transitioning into one particular future state is rarely 1.
We can see that the stochastic kernel is a collection of probability measures that tells us how the system evolves over time. If we start in a particular state and choose a particular control input, there is a probability that at the next time we will reach some future state. This evolution through time is governed by the dynamics of the system, the control inputs we choose, and by the stochastic disturbance. We typically only have control over the inputs to the system, and so we would like to determine a way to choose the control inputs so that we maximize safety.
So how do we define a stochastic reachability problem? We start by defining a safe set $\mathcal{K} \in \mathscr{B}(\mathcal{X})$, which is the feasible region of the state space, and a target set $\mathcal{T} \in \mathscr{B}(\mathcal{X})$, which is a region of the state space where we want to end up. The goal, then, is to determine the probability that a system will reach $\mathcal{T}$ while avoiding $\mathcal{X}\backslash\mathcal{K}$ for all time $k \in [0, N]$.
$$V_{N}(x) ={} \boldsymbol{1}_{\mathcal{T}}(x)$$ $$V_{k}(x) ={} \boldsymbol{1}_{\mathcal{K}}(x)\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{y} \sim Q(\cdot|x, u)}[V_{k+1}(\boldsymbol{y})]$$

title: Stochastic Reachability

summary: We present a data-driven solution to the terminal-hitting stochastic reachability problem for a Markov control process. We employ a nonparametric representation of the stochastic kernel as a conditional distribution embedding within a reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS). This representation avoids intractable integrals in the dynamic recursion of the stochastic reachability problem since the expectations can be calculated as an inner product within the RKHS. We demonstrate this approach on a high-dimensional chain of integrators and on Clohessy-Wiltshire-Hill dynamics.
title: Model-Free Stochastic Reachability Using Kernel Distribution Embeddings

summary: We present a solution to the first-hitting time stochastic reachability problem for extremely high-dimensional stochastic dynamical systems. Our approach takes advantage of a nonparametric learning technique known as conditional distribution embeddings to model the stochastic kernel using a data-driven approach. By embedding the dynamics and uncertainty within a reproducing kernel Hilbert space, it becomes possible to compute the safety probabilities for stochastic reachability problems as simple matrix operations and inner products. We employ a convergent approximation technique, random Fourier features, in order to accommodate the large sample sets needed for high-dimensional systems. This technique avoids the curse of dimensionality, and enables the computation of safety probabilities for high-dimensional systems without prior knowledge of the structure of the dynamics or uncertainty. We validate this approach on a double integrator system, and demonstrate its capabilities on a million-dimensional, nonlinear, non-Gaussian, repeated planar quadrotor system.
title: Stochastic Reachability for Systems up to a Million Dimensions
